text: Field artillery in the American Civil War were cannon that could be moved around the battlefield or could travel with an army unit. Field artillery could only fight unlimbered (disconnected from the cart and horses that pulled it). The limber (or caisson) along with the team of six horses would be moved to a safe area nearby. Gun crews were organized into an artillery battery, six guns (later in the war, four) were deployed along a line about wide with the guns spaced about apart. At times the horses remained hitched to the limber or caisson so the battery could move quickly. An artillery crew was made up of eight highly trained men. An artillery battery had a total of between 70 and 100 soldiers. There were several types of field artillery used during the Civil War. These included the 6 pounder gun, 12 and the 24 pound Howitzer, the famous Model 1857 12-Pounder Napoleon Field Gun, the 3 inch Ordnance rifle and the 10 and 20 pound Parrott rifle. Most cannons were muzzleloading weapons. Cannon barrels were of two types. One was the older smoothbore cannons as used during the Mexican–American War. They usually had barrels made of bronze and fired round iron cannonballs. The newer type was the rifled cannon that were made of cast iron and wrought iron. They fired Bullet-shaped shells. Both guns and ammunition had a tendency to be unreliable and they were dangerous to shoot. == Smoothbore cannon == Before the outbreak of the American Civil War, the United States government did not encourage any new developments in ordnance. Most ordnance experts in the U.S. Ordnance Department were older military officers who believed what worked during the Mexican–American War would work now and did not need improving. Inventors had to go through years of field experiments and political red tape just to get their ideas introduced. Most used their own money and could lose all their money trying to introduce a new idea. Early cannons were identified by the term "pounder" (abbreviated "pdr"). This referred to the weight of the cannonball the gun fired. For example, a 12 pounder fired a round solid piece of steel. In the 17th century, when howitzers were developed, the term pounder began to be used less and less although it was used through the Civil War. Smooth bores included both guns and howitzers. Both had shorter barrels and used a higher trajectory. Both were less accurate than rifled cannons. The Model 1857 12-pounder Napoleon with its green barrel made up 40% of the cannons on both sides. It was the most commonly used cannon. They were heavy at making them hard for the six-horse team to pull. The gun crew of the Napoleon was made up of six men. It could fire a ball, shell or canister shot out to a range of at a speed of 1,440 feet per second (or 439 meters per second). It used a charge of of black powder. The Union made 1,156 units while the Confederacy made 501. Because they did not have the manufacturing capacity of the North, Confederates attempted to capture as many Union-made Napoleon 12-pounders as they could. The Model 1857 was made to replace the Model 1841 6-pounder but both were used during the Civil War out of necessity. For ranges of or less the most effective field piece was the Model 1842 12-pounder Howitzer. It weighed only and could easily be moved into position by hand. Its large shells gave it very good firepower but its short range (just over ) was less than that of the 6-pounder gun. They were easy targets for enemy artillery that usually had greater range. They were popular for close infantry support. At the Battle of Gettysburg, nine of these were supposed to accompany Pickett's Charge. Because of some confusion among the Confederate ranks regarding the orders and very accurate Union artillery fire, all nine were taken out of the battle before Pickett's men crossed the field. The smoothbore guns remained the most favored technology during the war.Edward Hagerman, The American Civil War and the Origins of Modern Warfare (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 1988), p. 22 == Rifled cannon == While used mostly by the Union army, rifled guns were still a new idea and were not very popular among artillery officers or field commanders. Rifled guns were designated by the diameter of the bore of the barrel in inches. In 1860, the Ordnance Board recommended that half of the existing bronze smoothbore cannons be rifled. But this weakened the cannons to the point they could not stand the strain of firing. So the experiment quickly ended. Ordinarily the barrels of smoothbore cannons only lasted about 500 rounds before having to be replaced. Rifled barrels proved to last much longer in field use. The British-made Armstrong and Whitworth guns were good weapons but there were not enough of them to have any major effect on the war. A problem with the rifled guns was they fired too far for the gunners to accurately see to range their targets. When artillery observers and balloons were used for artillery spotting, this increased the accuracy of the rifled guns. Training artillery crews in the use of rifled guns took longer and was more difficult. General George McClellan was among the Union officers who felt that the American terrain was not well suited for the very long range of these weapons. Jefferson Davis, the Confederate President was of the same opinion. All these factors contributed to the slow acceptance of rifled cannon. The cannon called the 3-inch Ordnance Rifle (also called the 3-inch Wrought Iron Rifle) was an early favorite of the Ordnance Board due to its accuracy. These and other rifled guns were distinguished by their black barrels. About 1,000 were bought during the war. They were made by the Phoenix Iron Works of Phoenixville, Pennsylvania. They were made of wrought iron strips bent on a mandrel then welded together. They were then machined into their final shape. The early prototypes were fired 500 times with no signs of wear. It was accurate and reliable in battle.Curt Johnson; Richard Claire Anderson, Artillery Hell: The Employment of Artillery at Antietam (College Station: Texas A & M University Press, 1995), pp. 24–25 The Confederacy also produced a 3-inch Ordnance Rifle. But the use of low-grade iron ore and poorer rifling machinery made these guns less reliable. Another popular rifled type were the Parrott rifles. The original 10-pound model had a bore of . This was changed to to standardize the round. They had cast iron barrels with a wrought iron reinforcement strip welded around the breech (rear of the cannon). == Artillery rounds == There were basically four types of artillery rounds used in the Civil War: * Solid Round Shot – This is a solid iron ball that could travel several miles. They were designed to crush the target. * Explosive Shell – This was a hollow round iron ball filled with black powder. It had a fuse to make the iron ball explode when it reached the target. People today occasionally find these buried in fields and backyards. They can still explode with deadly results. * Spherical case – It is also filled with gunpowder and uses a fuse. The hollow area is also filled with small iron balls. Used against troops it was usually timed to go off at chest-level. Case shot was designed to kill or injure enemy soldiers at maximum distance the cannon could fire.Jack Bell, Civil War Heavy Explosive Ordnance (Denton, TX: University of North Texas Press, 2003), p. 43 * Canister Shot – Like spherical case it is a shrapnel round used against enemy troop formations. It contains usually between 20 and 30 large solid round balls. When fired it spreads out in a cone shape from the muzzle like a large shotgun blast. When canister balls were scarce, nails, scrap iron or other materials were used. Canister was a short range weapon usually effective at up to .Shane Mountjoy; Tim McNeese, Technology and the Civil War (New York: Chelsea House Publishers, 2009), p. 46 Some artillery commanders used a technique of firing canister at the ground in front of advancing troops. The effect was to bounce the canister shot into the formation and cause more deaths. == Gun crews == For the average artillery piece it took eight highly trained artillerymen to form a gun crew. Each member of the crew was cross-trained to do all the jobs required to operate a gun.American Civil War: The Definitive Encyclopedia and Document Collection, ed. Spencer C. Tucker (Santa Barbara, CA ABC-CLIO, LLC, 2013), pp. 89–90 If a crew member was killed or wounded, another member of the crew could take his place. Gun crews were among the best trained soldiers in either the Confederate or Union armies. They were also vulnerable. They had to see their target to hit it. If they could see their target, the enemy soldiers they were targeting could see them. For a gun crew to get off the maximum number of accurate rounds per minute, they used a system whereby each man had a number. His number indicated his main task: * Number 1 - Sponges out the barrel to wet down any hot spots or sparks. He then rams the round (cannonball and powder or shell) down the barrel. * Number 2 - Uses a "worm" (a large corkscrew on a pole) to make sure there is nothing caught in the barrel. He then loads the round and charge in the barrel ready for ramming. * Number 3 - Covers the vent hole with his thumb wearing a special glove. He then pierces the loaded powder bag with a spike. * Number 4 - Places the friction primer in the vent hole just prepared by Number 3. On the command of "fire" he pulls the lanyard attached to the primer which fires the gun. * Number 5 - Carries the round from the limber to the artillery piece. * Number 6 - In charge of the ammunition box on the limber and prepares the friction primers. * Number 7 - Hands the round each time to Number 5. * Gunner - Aligns and aims the artillery piece. Each gun or artillery piece had a sergeant who commanded the gun. == Battery personnel == * Section commander - A lieutenant commanded a "section" of two guns. * Battery commander - A captain usually commanded the battery of six guns (four guns in a Confederate battery). * First Sergeant - Also called an Orderly Sergeant, he helped the battery commander with administrative duties.John McKay, Brave Men in Desperate Times: The Lives of Civil War Soldiers (Guilford, CT: TwoDot, 2007), pp. 41–42 He was second-in- command to his Captain. * Quartermaster Sergeant - Was responsible for supply and logistics. * Artificer - A blacksmith who repaired cannons. * Farrier - Kept the horses shod. * Bugler - One or two per battery. A bugler was usually at the battery commander's side and the bugle could be heard over a considerable distance. Artillery bugle calls were nearly identical to cavalry bugle calls.Artillery Bugle Signals Manual. ed. R.J. Samp (Illinois: ACW Buglers Press, 2002), p. 3 * Guidon - Carried the battery colors. He was often the most trusted man in the unit. * Teamsters and Wagoneers - To manage all the horse teams and wagons needed to move the battery. == Notes == == References == == Other websites == * Civil War Artillery Glossary * * * Firing the 12-pdr Napoleon; National Park Service recreation * Category:American Civil War Category:Artillery
